With his smoking, hard-hitting ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œFunk UnitÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½, the man with the Red Horn has been responsible for a bunch of successful CDs over the past years. His concerts from Stockholm to Beijing have been met with ecstatic acclamation. In duo with pianist EsbjÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â¶rn Svensson, he has elevated Swedish folk music to the level of subdued works of art. As the artistic director of the 2001 Berlin Jazz Festival, designed a state of the art presentation of Scandinavian trends and moods.

 <a href="
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kristina_Lugn" rel="nofollow" target="_NEW">
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kristina_Lugn</a>

Gunhild Bricken Kristina Lugn (born November 14, 1948) is a Swedish poet and dramatist and member of the Swedish Academy. She was born in Tierp, Uppland and was raised in SkÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â¶vde, VÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â¤stergÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â¶tland, and after finishing her academic education she has devoted her time to poetry, as literary critic and a playwright. Since 1972 she has published seven books of poetry. Since the 1990s Lugn also belongs to the most beloved and appreciated playwrights of today&#039;s Sweden. Her plays have been staged at the Dramaten (the Swedish Royal Dramatic Theatre), Stockholms stadsteater (Stockholm City Theatre) and at Teater Brunnsgatan Fyra, a.o. Much appreciated by the Swedish audience, she touches subjects of loneliness, death and middle-age crises with irony, cynicism and black humour. She has been awarded several awards.

Since 1997 she runs the small independent theatre Teater Brunnsgatan Fyra in Stockholm (at the address of Brunnsgatan 4), established by the popular Swedish actor Allan Edwall.

Her surname "Lugn" also means "calm" in Swedish; a double meaning she jokes with and uses.

On December 20, 2006, Lugn was elected into the Swedish Academy to replace Lars Gyllensten in chair 14.
